post_text: Last autumn, the USC boys golf team went undefeated until finishing runner-up to Fox Chapel in the WPIAL team finals. That lone loss prevented the Panthers from advancing to the PIAA championships. This year, the Panthers again have set the bar high. The team‚Äôs goals are to win the section, qualify for the team championships, win the WPIAL title and go on to states.

Tuesday, Sept. 22; 4-5 p.m.
Wednesday, Sept. 23; 7-8 a.m.

Orders must be submitted by noon on Tuesday, Sept. 15. (https://forms.gle/gLnw5WVAzav5Qbfj7)

post_text: Ethan Dahlem is one of the best dual-threat quarterbacks in the WPIAL. Last season was his first as a starter and he was splendid, averaging 264 yards of offense a game. He completed 142 of 210 passes for 2,218 yards and 17 touchdowns and also ran for 951 yards on 211 attempts and scored 15 touchdowns.

post_text:
Upper St. Clair School District will offer free breakfast and lunch to all students ‚Äì regardless of ability to pay. Students can receive school meals each day whether they are learning in-person or at home.

Citing the unprecedented nature of the pandemic, the U.S. Department of Agriculture recently extended waivers nationwide that allow meals to be served to students in-person and/or via pick-up at no cost through the end of 2020 or until funding runs out. Read more: https://tinyurl.com/yy5xz5xj

post_text: The USC girls' golf team halted a 14-year WPIAL title drought when it upended four-time defending champion North Allegheny last season to win the school‚Äôs 17th Class 3A team golf title and finish second in the PIAA finals at Heritage Hills in York. The Panthers return several key players from last year‚Äôs squad, including junior Tori Slagle, who finished sixth in the WPIAL.

Upper St. Clair girls golf team anxiously awaits opportunity to defend title
text:
The USC girls' golf team halted a 14-year WPIAL title drought when it upended four-time defending champion North Allegheny last season to win the school‚Äôs 17th Class 3A team golf title and finish second in the PIAA finals at Heritage Hills in York. The Panthers return several key players from last year‚Äôs squad, including junior Tori Slagle, who finished sixth in the WPIAL.

post_text:
Upper St. Clair rising senior Reshma Gudla and recent graduate Vivek Babu recently created a local test prep book sharing venture - Book Buddies. This initiative enables high school students to donate their test prep books (ex. SAT or ACT books) and buy new ones for cheaper prices through their online store.

Reshma and Vivek plan to donate 100% of the proceeds to local charities. This project is supported through a mini-grant from the Community Foundation of Upper St. Clair. To learn more, visit: https://bookbuddies.squarespace.com/

Jake Slinger thought his heart‚Äôs desires lay somewhere in northern Virginia. However, after a yearlong adventure at George Mason University, the USC native learned what Dorothy Gayle from Kansas knew all along. ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs no place like home,‚Äù Slinger said.

18 Things Homeschooling Made Us Appreciate About Teachers
text:
National Teacher Appreciation Week kicks off tomorrow. We are so incredibly grateful for our dedicated teachers and the important work they do each day, every day. This spring has challenged all of us to do things differently - and they have responded brilliantly. Thank you!!!!! üêæ‚ù§Ô∏è

post_text:
Ryan Klingensmith from www.shapethesky.org is hosting a free webinar this Thursday, April 23 from 6-6:30 p.m. Click below to register.

Title: Parenting in a Digital World: Dangerous Apps???

Description: Are there really dangerous apps? Ryan will discuss the concept of "dangerous apps" and help the attendees think differently about apps and youth behavior.

Do your kids use TikTok, YOLO, Snapchat, LMK or Hoop? You may know what these are, you may not...but kids do! Are these apps dangerous? Let Ryan help guide you to a different way of thinking about kids and apps.

shared_text:
The College Board
April 15 at 3:03 PM ¬∑

With student and educator safety as our priority, we're adapting to the challenges presented by Covid-19. While we're unable to administer the June SAT, we will:
‚óºÔ∏è Have an SAT each month, starting with August
‚óºÔ∏è Significantly expand capacity for fall SATs

Registration for fall SAT dates will open in May. Students who were registered for the canceled June SAT and juniors who don't have SAT scores will have early access to registration for the August, September, and October administrations.

More details: http://spr.ly/61881FjN8.

All gift cards and monetary donations will be distributed to families/individuals that need help with their basic needs (groceries, utility bills, etc.) SHIM has asked for gift cards to the following stores: Giant Eagle, Aldi and Walmart ($5-$20 gift card value). Monetary donations in any amount.

post_text:
USCHS sophomore Vidhur Senthil received a mini grant through the Community Foundation of Upper St. Clair to offer a voluntary grocery delivery service. Vidhur will coordinate volunteers to deliver groceries to USC residents who are essential workers or those at a high risk of contracting COVID-19. These people may include busy doctors, senior citizens and people with pre-existing conditions.

This service will have no extra delivery fee making it very accessible for everyone. The grant will be used to provide 25 $10 gift cards, which will be given to volunteers who complete three deliveries. Vidhur has created online forms for those interested in delivery or volunteering:

Delivery sign up: https://forms.gle/XcKdhuPTQnaCrdmJA
Volunteer sign up: https://forms.gle/ydzFSFf6ZNL22Hqq8

For more information, contact Vidhur at grocerydelivery412@gmail.com.

post_text: As Kid President says, "we could all use a pep talk." Remote learning starts this Thursday, April 2. It's a brand new journey for ALL of us. It may not be perfect at first but we'll make improvements and adjustments along the way. Patience. Understanding. Communication. We've got this USC! ‚ö´Ô∏è‚ö™Ô∏è‚ù§Ô∏è
shared_text:
Kid President
January 24, 2017 at 2:30 PM ¬∑

We gave this Pep Talk to the world EXACTLY four years ago today.
A LOT has changed since then, but one thing has stayed certain: We all STILL have a duty to give the world a reason to dance.

Thank you so much for joining our joyful rebellion over the past years. We sure do have a lot more work to do, pep talks to give, and dance moves to make up on the spot - we're SO glad you're here with us.

Keep going. Keep going. Keep going.

post_text: Today, Gov. Tom Wolf announced that PA‚Äôs public school districts will remain closed indefinitely. USCSD had planned to remain closed until at least April 14. The district‚Äôs closure will now extend at least until the statewide closure expires. As previously planned, remote learning will begin this Thursday, April 2, and continue throughout our closure.
text: Today, Gov. Tom Wolf announced that PA‚Äôs public school districts will remain closed indefinitely. USCSD had planned to remain closed until at least April 14. The district‚Äôs closure will now extend at least until the statewide closure expires. As previously planned, remote learning will begin this Thursday, April 2, and continue throughout our closure.

post_text: A group of our USCHS student council senators had a mission this week to use social media to connect and lift spirits. They decided to host a "Quarantine Spirit Week" using their @uscstuco Instagram account. Each day had a theme and anyone in the community could send in submissions to be reposted on their account by 2:20 p.m., which is when the last bell rings on a typical day at the high school. The photo with the most "likes" by 5 p.m. each day was awarded a gift card via email. They created a video montage of all the submissions for the community to enjoy and feel connected. Mission accomplished!

post_text:
This afternoon Gov. Tom Wolf issued a stay-at-home order for residents of Pennsylvania‚Äôs hardest-hit areas ‚Äì including Allegheny County ‚Äì to help combat the spread of COVID-19.

In response to this new measure, ALL Upper St. Clair School District properties, fields and playgrounds are CLOSED. This includes the high school stadium and track as well as the turf field at Boyce Middle School. Where possible, gates and fences are now locked. In addition, signs will be posted noting the facility closure. These measures are effective immediately and will remain in place until further notice.
https://tinyurl.com/vz9f83a

post_text: So pleased to share that earlier today the Pa. Department of Education announced the cancellation of the state's PSSA, PASA, and Keystone Exams that were scheduled for this spring. This is a welcome relief amidst a very uncertain period of time in education. We are grateful that our energy and efforts can continue to be devoted to addressing our students‚Äô most pressing needs.
shared_text:

March 19 at 4:16 PM ¬∑

More info: https://www.media.pa.gov/Pages/Education-Details.aspx?newsid=813

post_text: The goal of most high schools is to have students graduate with skills that prepare them for success in life. One indication the school is making good on that intention is its building-level performance score ‚Äî which is used to evaluate teachers and principals under PA‚Äôs Educator Effectiveness System (Act 82 of 2012). The measure was previously known as the School Performance Profile. Tops in Allegheny County for 2019 was Upper St. Clair High School, with a score of 97.6 out of 100.

post_text:
All year long, North Allegheny and Upper St. Clair have been two of the best defensive teams in the WPIAL, with each allowing an average of less than 40 points per game.

Things were no different when the teams met on Tuesday night with a berth in the WPIAL Class 6A championship game on the line. But it was the Tigers (21-3) who took their shutdown defense to a whole new level to earn a trip to the title game for the fifth year in a row, as North Allegheny shut out the Panthers (14-8) for the entire second quarter on its way to a 39-27 win.
shared_text:
POST-GAZETTE.COM
Girls 6A semifinals: North Allegheny shuts down Upper St. Clair, Bethel Park moves past Mt. Lebanon
text:
All year long, North Allegheny and Upper St. Clair have been two of the best defensive teams in the WPIAL, with each allowing an average of less than 40 points per game.

But it was the Tigers (21-3) who took their shutdown defense to a whole new level to earn a trip to the title game for the fifth year in a row, as North Allegheny shut out the Panthers (14-8) for the entire second quarter on its way to a 39-27 win.

The project, which kicked-off on Friday, Feb. 14 is part of the school‚Äôs No Place for Hate initiative through the Anti-Defamation League.

post_text:
REMINDER: The USC Parent Teacher Council (PTC) is hosting a district-wide drive to benefit the families served by SHIM. Donations can be dropped off at all USC schools.

Some of the items most needed include:

* Dried beans
* Lentils
* Baking products (flour, sugar, oil, etc.)
* Pasta sauce in jars
* Soup
* Boxed rice mixes
* Cereal & Oatmeal
* Canned proteins (tuna, chicken, salmon, beans)
* Spices and seasonings
* Condiments
* Beverages (juice, tea, coffee)
* Diapers, sizes 3-6
* Personal care items (shampoo, toothbrushes, toothpaste, deodorant, feminine items, etc.)
shared_text:

post_text: Upper St. Clair missed its first 12 shots from 3-point range Friday night at Fox Chapel. But once the Panthers starting hitting, there was no stopping them as Upper St. Clair spoiled the Foxes‚Äô bid for an undefeated regular season 61-46 before a capacity crowd and a playoff atmosphere.
shared_text:

post_text:
Two USCHS students recently earned first place finishes at the Pennsylvania Junior Academy of Science Region 7 competition on Feb. 1 at Duquesne University ‚Äì advancing to the state-level competition.

Freshman Keshav Narasimhan completed independent research and a presentation titled, ‚ÄúA Mathematical Model to Predict Crohn's Flare-Up.‚Äù Junior Sophia Shi, who participated in a research internship with the UPMC Aging Institute last summer, focused her research/presentation on, ‚ÄúRegulation of Deubitiquinase Activity in Mitophagy.‚Äù

post_text: Members of the USC School Board unanimously approved the appointment of Jennifer Schnore to the board of school directors on Monday, Jan. 27. She fills the vacancy created by the resignation of Dante Plutko. Mrs. Schnore will serve the remaining two years of the four-year term, which expires in December 2021.

She fills the vacancy created by the resignation of Dante Plutko. Mrs. Schnore will serve the remaining two years of the four-year term, which expires in December 2021.

post_text:
Kindergarten registration for incoming Upper St. Clair kindergarten students and their families will be held late-March and early-April at each of the district‚Äôs three elementary schools as follows:

Baker Elem.: Tues, March 24 & Thurs, April 2
Eisenhower Elem.: Wed, March 25 & Tues, March 31
Streams Elem.: Thurs, March 26 & Wed, April 1

Appointments, which last approximately 20 minutes, will be scheduled between 8 a.m. and 3 p.m. on each of the registration days. Online appointment scheduling will begin in February.
shared_text:
USCSD.K12.PA.US

text:
Kindergarten registration for incoming Upper St. Clair kindergarten students and their families will be held late-March and early-April at each of the district‚Äôs three elementary schools as follows:

Baker Elem.: Tues, March 24 & Thurs, April 2
Eisenhower Elem.: Wed, March 25 & Tues, March 31
Streams Elem.: Thurs, March 26 & Wed, April 1

post_text: Overwhelmed? Exhausted? No matter your profession, there are challenging spells throughout the arc of a career. How can you avoid burnout? post_text: Due to a power outage USCHS will be dismissing early today - beginning at 12:15 p.m. All other schools have power. However, phones and Internet service are down at Fort Couch, Eisenhower and the bus garage - calls have been rerouted to the district administration center.

post_text: Congrats to our 28 Boyce Middle School students were recently honored with November Boyce Pride Awards for being kind and making their school more AWESOME! üôåüêæ
shared_text:

post_text:
The always-optimistic, first-year field general Mike Junko considered Upper St. Clair‚Äôs 2019 football campaign spectacular.

The Panthers opened the season with a stunning upset win over South Fayette, the 2018 WPIAL Class 4A champion, and preceded to clinch a playoff berth in the challenging Allegheny Eight Conference before being eliminated in the quarterfinals of the WPIAL Class 5A tournament.

shared_text:
Upper St. Clair School District added 21 new photos.
November 12, 2019 at 4:53 PM ¬∑

Thank you to the hundreds of parents, teachers, students and community members who were able to join us last night for UnSelfie with Dr. Michele Borba. It was truly an honor to partner with so many individuals and organizations who share our commitment to kids and families including St. Paul's Episcopal Church and St. Paul‚Äôs Episcopal Nursery School in Mt. Lebanon, the USC Parent Teacher Council Wellness Committee, the Youth Steering Committee of USC and the Community Foundation of USC.

Coincidentally, tomorrow (Nov. 13) is World Kindness Day. This is a great opportunity to work on Dr. Borba's 9 Essential Empathy Habits -- #6 Practice KINDNESS.

post_text: Two USC middle school teams placed first in their respective divisions at the regional History Bowl on Nov. 7 at the Senator John Heinz History Center. Finishing first in the 6-8 division was the Fort Couch team of 7th graders Jamie Barrett, Eva Dubreil, Ryan Hyatt and Rohan Mehta. The 4-5 division winners included Boyce 5th graders Augusta Bottonari, Kenzie Pope, Catalina Ramirez and Jonah Zahalsky.

post_text: This October, Pennsylvania senators unanimously passed a bill to end child marriage. And two extraordinary teachers are largely responsible for its success. English teacher Daniela Buccilli and social studies teacher Leah Humes started Pennsylvania‚Äôs first integrated gender studies class at Upper St. Clair High School in Pittsburgh.

This October, Pennsylvania senators unanimously passed a bill to end child marriage. And two extraordinary teachers are largely responsible for its success. English teacher Daniela Buccilli and social studies teacher Leah Humes started Pennsylvania‚Äôs first integrated gender studies class at Upper St. Clair High School in Pittsburgh.

post_text: Steve Miller worked first as a software developer. Janet Waldeck started out as a research scientist. But both left their initial careers to get into the teaching profession. And last month, both area teachers received the Presidential Award for Excellence in Mathematics & Science Teaching, the highest honor the U.S. government bestows on high school math and science teachers.
shared_text:

Janet Waldeck of Allderdice and Steve Miller of Upper St. Clair received Presidential Awards for Excellence in math and science education.

post_text: Are you curious about gifted and talented education (GATE) in the USC School District? If so, please join us at 1 p.m. this Friday, Nov. 8, in the USC Township Library multipurpose room. Assistant Director of Student Support Services Lauren Madia will discuss what is gifted?; gifted education in USC; staffing; the process for identifying and evaluating giftedness; and resources for parents.

post_text: Upper St. Clair High School is taking steps to give students the knowledge they need to make good financial decisions, both now and in the future. Topics covered include basic skills like filling out bank deposit slips and checks, tax forms, budgeting, credit card versus debit card use, credit scores, retirement, investment and compound interest, rent versus buy decisions, the cost of higher education and job research.

post_text: Coming up next week....Join us at 7 p.m. on Monday, Nov. 11 at USCHS for an important discussion of what parents and educators can do to combat the growing empathy crisis among children today. Author Michele Borba will offer solutions for today's families.

post_text: The 24th annual Madrigal Dinner is set for Saturday, Nov. 23, at the Westminster Church Fellowship Hall. Enjoy a Medieval dinner, feasting on chicken Wellington, side dishes and desserts along with wassail, coffee and tea. The cost is $35 for adults and $23 for children age 12 and under. Purchase tickets online by Nov. 8 to save $5 per ticket.
